newsitem.title: USA: New England storm damage said "in tens of millions".
newsitem.headline: New England storm damage said "in tens of millions".

text.p: A storm that poured more than a foot-and-a-half (0.5 metre) of rain on parts of the New England region caused damages estimated "in the tens of millions" of dollars emergency management officials said Tuesday.
The storm damaged roads and bridges, flooded homes and caused havoc to the area's transportation systems.
The head of the Massachusetts Emergency Management Agency, Peter LaPorte, in a telephone interview said the storm caused "tens of millions (of dollars) in damages" to the eastern part of the state.

New Hampshire Gov. Stephen Merrill, said through a spokesman that more than 40 communities in eight of the state's 10 counties had reported some loss. "We have a rough preliminary estimate of $5-to-$7 million in damages," said Merrill's spokesman Jim Rivers.
In Maine, "we're estimating damages of at least $10 million," said a spokesman for Gov. Angus King.
King said a request would be made for federal emergency assistance.
Rainwater runoff broke the primary supply pipe of the Portland Water District, leaving 140,000 residents of the state's largest city and surrounding communities without drinking water Tuesday.
Police said at least one person had been reported missing.
Authorities in New Hampshire kept a close eye on the Saco and Lamprey rivers that were both above flood stage. Rivers in Massachusetts were slowly dropping from rainfall received over the weekend.
Dams also remained a concern in Northern New England. Residents near Highland Lake in Westbrook, Maine, were urged to evacuate Tuesday after water began flowing around the lake's dam.

"A Deluge of Misery" read a banner headline in the Portland Press Herald. Portland received 12.27 inches (29.7 cm) of rain from the storm that began late (on) Sunday -- three times what it normally gets in the entire month of October.
Travel remained tricky throughout the region. A 100-foot section of the Maine Turnpike was washed out.
In Boston, portions of the subway system remained closed because of flood damage on Monday to Kenmore Square, an important junction, which remained under water, a day after the storm left the city.

But Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority officials, who operate Boston's subway system were actually pleased Tuesday afternoon. Pumps had been able lower the water covering the tracks to six-and-a-half feet from 20-feet on Monday.
